title:
Star Shearing Season -- Transient Signals in Wave-like Dark Matter
  Experiments from Black Hole Formation
abstract:
Ordinary matter coupled to light weakly interacting bosons can lead to the
formation of a macroscopic bosonic field in the vicinity of large matter
concentrations such as ordinary or neutron stars. When these objects are turned
into black holes due to a supernova or a binary merger this ''hair'' could be
''shorn'' off. Part of the field configuration would then be released leading
to an outgoing field wave. For small masses this field transient remains rather
compact and can induce a transient signal in experiments, in particular those
that look for wave-like dark matter. This signal can be correlated with the
corresponding astrophysical signal of the event. In this note, we consider a
variety of couplings and the associated signals and estimate the corresponding
sensitivities.
